This claim gets one big mistake: while Donald Trump won the prize, called the Medal of Honor for Ellis Island, it was not for "work within the black community." We've reached out to Ellis Island's honorary association, which runs the award. Society is a non-political organization that promotes diversity and understanding among religious and ethnic groups, as well as the restoration and preservation of Ellis Island. The spokesman, Otto Coca Poletti Fact, reported that Trump was one of several persons to be awarded the medal of honour for Ellis Island in 1986 - the first year in which it was given (the same year Parks and Ali were also beneficiaries). The medallion has changed over the years, as Coca said, and now beneficiaries are selected for charitable efforts as well as other contributions. According to an article published on 16 October 1986 in The New York Times, those invited to the Award were selected from more than 15,000 nominations. The article states that the winners were "a mixture of relatively prominent and unknown citizens" and were screened by the National Ethnic Alliance of Organizations. The article lists Trump as a recipient, with a "German developer" along with his name. A photo taken on October 27, 1986 by Jetty Yvonne Hemsey shows Trump standing next to Parks and Ali at the reception to honour the recipients. Joe DiMaggio, Victor Burg and Anita Bryant also appear in the picture. "It has nothing to do with the race," said Coca about the picture. "They were all honored for different reasons and they were all standing together, that's the only reason the picture exists."
